Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2008 07:18PM - edited Jan 31, 2008 07:23PM by 40somethingMom I just bumped up to the 3.5 tennis USTA level before I was diagnosed, I am finding it hard to be away from my game, do you really think playing during treatment is doable?  I live in Michigan, we play indoor now,I was playing 3 days a week before all of this!   but I did not register for the winter session because my onc suggested against, I had a right mastectomy looking at 12wks of CT reconstruction in the Fall--  I would love to hear if you pull off playing.I hope to start up again after chemo, before reconstruction, at least that is my thoughts for now.
Posts.Title: head cover while playing tennis pacmom pacmom

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2008 03:49PM - edited Feb 6, 2008 03:50PM by 40somethingMom Margaret, My sister plays tennis on Amelia Island, Fernandidna- she calls to tell me her play by plays all the time, I love listening since I've been away from it.  I just wanted to say, I think the way I feel this week, much better, that I am planning to hit with a partner though all of this.(my oncologist tells me to be careful with the port, which I will) I just e mailed a tennis buddy and plan to start up in a week.  I pray your first treatment goes well.
Posts.Title: head cover while playing tennis pacmom pacmom

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2008 12:47PM - edited Feb 1, 2008 12:48PM by 40somethingMom Just started 1/29,4 rounds of CT planned every 3 weeks, then tamoxifin.  Not up to playing this week, tired  , a little constipation, diarrhea.  Maybe I will have a good week to come to fit in some hitting to keep my game up.  I'm pretty sad I was really playing well as of late and my serves were becoming great with spin, placement ... now I'm not sure what to expect with the mastectomy on my right serving side.
Posts.Title: head cover while playing tennis pacmom pacmom

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2008 11:26PM - edited Feb 19, 2008 11:31PM by 40somethingMom CPW--Yes I am inspired by you! THANKS  I plan to hit next week with a girl between tx #2 & #3, I was wondering what to do with the hair, I think I'll do the halo wig in pig tails(hair temples down only much cooler with no hair on the crown) , and a bandanna or my baseball hat on top.  and yes sticky tape, I have used that for tops and dresses works well. I hope I can keep my 3.5 rating! Did you have the expanders immediatly?  I am waiting till after chemo, just wonder how that might have went. I have an expensive wig I have not been using too much yet,seems to be itchy and a little tight and hair could be thinned more to match what I'm use to, I had it hand made and I have a recheck/size/style day next week --I need to build the courage to tell them my complaints and have them adjust it for me. The color and overall style looks just like the old me!--- but I'm real glad I have options.  Around the house I love my bandanna's.

Posts.Title: Starting chemo in April haykat57 angie27

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2008 08:35AM - edited Feb 12, 2008 08:53AM by 40somethingMom I agree, everyone is different, something I was amazed with when I discovered how individual every cancer diagnosis can be.  I made a vow to try and understand each person in my future when they say "I have cancer" be more understanding, sympathetic, something I never would have understood until I had this diagnosis myself!  I too have two older sisters tons of cousins and no family history. I also am so relieved when I hear someone feels or has symptoms I am having-- for me it makes me feel it's not all in my head. Oddly that is one reason I put off having my 1st mammogram, I felt the lump but thought I was imaging things.  I also vow to be an advicate to young women to NOT IGNORE any lump!  And do not ask your boyfriend or husband(bless their hearts) if they feel it too, go directly to the doctors. I appreciate every exchange of idea or imput on this site---but the idea to exchange  gifts is too much for me juggling the house, kids and all these appointments makes my head spin.  My husband also is so busy with work and trying to make appointments with me. (I'm trying to find the time to thank all the wonderful people who have sent me warm wishes and are helping me though all of this) I feel sorry for those having to pay for the wig, my insurance will cover, but we have a high deductible and seeing my treatment has been in two calender years we are screwed with two years of high deductible!!  I know the exchange rate thing I would call and dispute the charge!  I have done that before and got my money back.
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2008 05:29AM - edited Feb 16, 2008 05:30AM by 40somethingMom Nowhat-  I laughed too at that comment, especially since I have been also saying it looks like my onc surgeon took a needle and deflated my breast.  He actually(with instructions from my plastic surgeon) did a great job creating a nipple with his closer from the mastectomy, I will reconstruct later.  Krista-  I was nauseous after my 2nd blood draw for about an hour and wondered if that was normal? Margaret- Good to hear your first tx went well, I hit (tennis)balls against the wall the other day at my gym. Arm felt great. Last week my hair all came out and I am adjusting, next week 2nd tx, I'm hoping if all goes well I will meet up with a friend the following week to hit.  Fingers crossed.  I have a cute tennis hat with the breast cancer logo, funny I bought it before I was diagnosed! I hope everyone is enjoying their weekends!  Cold here in Michigan, I was suppose to be in Florida this week, Oh well, at least I have all of you to hang out with.
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2008 07:18PM - edited Feb 21, 2008 07:25PM by 40somethingMom As I understand it, the dexamethasone(steroid) is for TC treatment, the taxotere has a high risk of allergic reaction.  Taxol is related to taxotere--- if you have not started that course yet, that may be why you are not on steroids at this time. Bridget, you are a Fabulous Feb Fighter no matter what, those expanders are putting up a fight with you.  So sorry to hear what is happening.  I'ts making me nervous as that is my choice of reconstruction.  I hope they come out with the stem cell reconstruction boobs by the time I'm ready LOL I did hear there is something in the works in Japan that was successful, but probably not available until my grandkids may need it.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 04:30PM - edited Mar 3, 2008 04:38PM by 40somethingMom Last few weeks I was all about the SE and discomfort,  now I will be the optimistic cancer patient since I'm in week 3 of TC heaven of tx #2 1/2 way marker!! and the SE are minimal---- What is Good About Having Been Diagnosed with BC: -my husband has been doing the dishes (occasionally) -seeing my kids trying hard to get along with each other -less cooking (home deliveries!) -not plucked a hair on my chin since tx began -opportunity for my children to learn courage & perseverance -being faced with evaluating life & acceptance -lasagna   -learning to knit -see my husband take the vow "sickness & health" without complaint -shop & buy like there's no tomorrow -meet & have great doctors -love & help of family -more lasagna -no blow dry, cut or color -new sofa -cuddling up with my dog -even more lasagna -have in-laws call more often -seeing myself bald -getting more scarves, hats, xoxxo -smooth legs -guilt-free excuse for tupperware parties -daily fresh flowers for the home from friends and-----becoming part of the Sisterhood & Survivor Group - Feb Fighters!
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 09:03AM 40somethingMom wrote: Yesterday I was crying about nothing and today I'm am feeling soo much  better, perks me up to read these blogs too Need to mention I too have the most wonderful husband we will be married 14 years this July.  He is the most wonderful supportive husband and father they just don't come much better.  Nolana- sorry to hear about your friend, I have a friend who by the way has BC and just found out her onc score is 11 & will not need chemo,yeah I'm so happy for her, we have discussed the friends who seem distant and uncomfortable around us, I think they are not evolved in their personal lives, many just do not get it, I know I did not understand all this until I was hit with it, so I try to forgive them and just surround myself with those who are trying to understand and help. C-Babe- sorry to hear 4-6 have been tough, same for me, not looking forward to next week and tx#3 Donna- glad your feeling better now Believer-  have you tried Acai Berry juice, suppose to be the highest antioxidant berry?? but $$ crazypam- that's MI's slogan-ha ha-we got lucky this time storm did not move up this far artsee- I love to H20 color, I will check out your site Rachel- the hat story sounded very nice Di53- sorry tohear about your reaction, & the itch I think we all want the answer for that Grannie- Ativan has been the best help for my sleep, during tx week I add benedryl to the mix I'm sure I forgot someone, Chris I hope you have a great weekend and everyone else--Patty

I need to ask my onc her reasoning Artsee- I checked in on TC site a minute ago-- hi again Chris- Oh that beach sounds wonderful, here in MI beaches are frozen---I'll have to listen to my crashing wave relaxation tape now Donna-  I agree with Susan about that employer!! Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2008 01:56PM - edited Mar 12, 2008 02:07PM by 40somethingMom Trumpet84- good luck on the 17th--May the luck of the Irish be with you-shamrocks at your doorstep & a host of friends that never ends Bridget - congrats welcome to chemo land-loved hearing about your family - the horses sound wonderful Crazypam- thanks for mentioning those daughter head rubs, my dear 11 year old was excited to help when I told her your story Guitargirl- hope return flight is uneventful as well Chris- yes thanks so much for the lovely beach description Krista- hope everything goes OK with your port Sissy, Marianne,C-Babe everyone else- welcome- not long from my memory is the scalp issues it gets better Day 1 after tx#3 & only racing heart and heavy chest over all feeling well cross fingers it continues, neulasta shot this evening --yuck--plan to take the vicaden next day regardless of how I feel this time Oh, Aurora-  the nasty period, still strong and annoying, but I do know mine is heavy partly due to the baseball size benign tumor they found in my uterus on that PET which will be addressed after chemo with tomoxifin or hysterectomy I will meet with my onc next week that subject ---just read about your rash again-- good luck at the onc apt today,  with an 8 year old son I could get imagine of your description connection to the fantastic 4 --ugh

Bridget(so sorry to hear about the tooth, amazing about all the wigs have fun with it), Rose(good for you babysitting, kids keep it real for me), Artsee(how much for a small h20 melons? with names on it? on your site I'm not sure which one is you?),  Nolana(I'm walking in both my city and the Detroit Race for Cure this year Yeah my favorite bandana I wear is from 3 years ago when we walked in honor of a friend) Susan(hope you're home safe)

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2008 09:15AM - edited Feb 23, 2008 09:16AM by 40somethingMom Laura-  Just let it out, the waiting and anxious feelings are the hardest part!  Hang in there, I'm praying for you!! Donna- My 1st tx was easier than this time!!, I was hyper & had some bathroom challenges---This time with my 2nd tx day 3-4(day after the nuelasta shot my heart started racing, my skin turned bright red, my face was puffy the second day and my hands started to swell and tingle, bone pain too, extreme fatigue) I tried the vicadan first not much relief and then I went for the STEROIDS since that was the only thing I changed from tx 1 and it really made a difference with in a few hours, my face got color, my heart calmed down......(OBVIOUSLY ALLERGIC REACTION),today/day4  I wake up feeling a lot like last time terrible taste some bone aches (which is consistent with taxotere STEROIDS do their job, I'll have to deal with the hyper feelings. No bathroom trouble with the softer vs laxative Nolana congrats on 1st treatment endured Aurora Love the hair! Bridget/Guitargirl/grannie/K anyone I misseed HAVE A GREAT WEEKEND FEB FIGHTERS!

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2008 07:39PM 40somethingMom wrote: Hi Aurora- where you been you must be out and about feeling better week 3-I'm very glad you will join the finish line with me soon.  I wish you guys were at my FGLB class-- i am doing better than last round,  fingers cx, I get hit hardest day 4-7 like most of us, so not there yet.  But I have a feeling this will be better than #3, worst thing today is fatigue a sore throat and drippy nose.   I have a CAT in 3 wks, to check my 5 mm lung nodule they found and it will check on that baseball size benign tumor in my pelvis as well.  Then an MRI after that to check my other side which also has benign tumors.  I'm ,jealous of all of you finished with reconstruction and finishing your chemo, but I am not sure if I want to do- I'm still overwhelmed I'm considering a prophylactic mastectomy (I think that's what you call it)and reconstruct both sides, my BRCA test and the other tests will help me to decide. ha sorry you asked I never want to do this again either Evie, Di53, pondfrogs, Donna, Chris, Susan, goldilocks, kim, bridget... everyone!  hugs
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2008 11:36AM 40somethingMom wrote: Good Morning, I'm in the thick of it all, got to sleep in though--thanks to my WONDERFUL MOM! GETTING THE KIDS OFF TO SCHOOL AND DOING A LOAD OF LAUNDRY, I JUST LOVE HAVING HER WITH ME & I realize lucky-- after each tx! It's day 4 last tx I had hot flashes all night last night woke me up at least 5 times on top of all the trips to pee--at least the liver is working getting those toxins processed killing off those cells and out of my body, I was having the hot flashes occasionally with last txs but more like cold sweats, last night it was heavy sweating with bad headaches.  I also have the heartburn(taking prilozec) this morning and there's the sore throat. I'm very fatigued all i feel like doing is reading these comments and laying on the couch this morning. I am being postitive I am signing up for my tennis league today and can not wait to start back into my regular workout routine!  I am getting my life back in order after all of this! Nolana- I had itching on my foot around tx2 but it went away for me I hope same for you Aurora- i am definitely doing reconstruction, I'm just so nervous what procedure to pick, you and kathyL sound happy with your implants/expanders, I'm looking into the diep as well still not sure what I will do - I'm just the type of person that can't make decisions easily I am a researcher. Good luck to all of you who will be having tx in the next week!  Patty

Bridget I hope the weekend went great with your activities and the weather was as nice as it was here Rose, Aurora, Di53 have a great day! I never thought I would experience these hot flashes at my age what an experience this has all been!

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2008 11:21AM 40somethingMom wrote: Can not help myself to reply again to the February Fighters,  Donna-I'm sorry the Chemo Blues has hit you, sounds very much what I went through. Those grandkids will get you out of feeling that way, but I think we all need to go through little of self pity or we would go crazy! Evie-sounds like you are doing real well, happy to hear you got a new lap top with all of this too, I love mine Aurora-yes, isn't it weird to think we move on from these threads that have helped us though this part of our treatment-- I love your last entry on how we could have met-- I'm glad I had you as a partner in all of this---you would have been a fun doubles partner in tennis we would have tore the courts up together Laurel- So sorry to hear you had the bad bone pain, hope today is better-- Di- Strength to you for the next weeks of treatment! I will be walking in the Detroit Walk and will have February Fighter on my shirt! Bridget- Good luck to you too with the rest of your tx's and I hope you find your way home next time, I have to laugh a little at that now that it's over for you, I ‘m sure it was not funny at the time Chris, Rose, Susan, good luck with Rads I wish for all of you to have the energy to get through without too much fatigue HAPPY SPRING ALL -OK now back to the spring cleaning I am avoiding-
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2008 01:42PM - edited Feb 9, 2008 02:03PM by 40somethingMom My first treatment went OK, I had a very not warm and fuzzy nurse, she did not even acknowledge it was my first treatment.  Thank goodness the ladies in the chemo room were all kind and shared their stories, having my husband there was the best.  The nurse acted upset that my sports bra I had on was in the way of the port she said honey this was not the right thing to wear, I asked her why no one told me what to wear, I really thought they would put us in gowns like every other time, little did I know.  anyhow all went well enough, benedryl put me to sleep, and the hospital gave out CD players with relaxation tape, which was very good.  The nurse taught my husband how to give me the nuelasta shot, in my stomach(which I hated and asked why there, she said that was were it had to be given)  once again not warm and fuzzy and come to find out from my onc that the shot can be given just about anywhere!  I like it in my arm.  First day was fine, rest of week was constipation and all the aches, now my head is tingling and I feel the hair will start to fall out soon it is day 11.  I did fit two days of light workout in second week!  This is all doable in my book.  I am so glad to have the opportunity to have tx and hopefully never have this cancer again.
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2008 12:39AM - edited Feb 11, 2008 12:49AM by 40somethingMom I am becoming addicted to this site, partly because I cannot sleep since I started chemo on 1/28, unless I take my Ativan, which I do not feel comfortable taking every night, thus I stay up and write Grannie-- I had the port and it was uncomfortable/sore(like Cookie puts it) the first couple weeks especially when I "tried" to sleep, now I am more use to it, I'm on the thin side and it sticks out, one woman at my chemo treatment said her's was placed to the side of her breast closer to her arm, I did not know there were options, mine is above my breast right where my bra strap lies, uncomfortable spot.  If you have a choice ask.  It does not hurt at all when they draw blood or place the needle for chemo. -BarbaraS---Thank you for your comment-- Are you having Neo-Adjuvant Therapy?  My Onc suggested that for me, but I went with surgery 1st because I was afraid to wait, sounds like yours is working out for you. This is starting week 3 and I feel great, but I'm anxious about my hair falling out, not so much because I will loose it, but the unknown, people keep saying "maybe you won't loose your hair" or "I know someone who had chemo and did not loose their hair"-- it all drives me nuts, especially since I already ordered a wig. Today it is day 12 of TX on Cytoxan& Taxotere my head has been tingling for a couple days and when I run my hand through my hair I get about 6-8 strands every time.  I think it's starting.  I guess time will tell.Expectation and Anxiety have been overriding emotions in all of this.
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2008 11:45PM - edited Feb 12, 2008 11:45PM by 40somethingMom Lisa-sorry to hear you are having the bad reaction to the steroids(I just can't sleep),today my onc gave me something stronger to get some zzz's.  My 8 year old son also has had some reactions to my diagnosis as well.  He does not want to sit by kids at school who are sick so he will not make mom sick(we try not to make him feel this way)  He came off his soccer field tired and said "Mom I'm so tired--  I think I have breast cancer" and the day I came home from surgery he told a neighbor, who did not know, "My mom had her cancer cut out today" I think this is all normal reactions for his age, trying to figure it all out for himself.
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2008 10:50PM - edited Feb 15, 2008 10:49AM by 40somethingMom Bee and Nolana, The fear of the unknown was the worse part for me as well, a good cry is cleansing(I'm still going through that)  I am also on TC and it has not been too bad.  I am anxious about my second treatment 2/18, I had the emend,ativan, steroids(I am to try less this time since I had such trouble sleeping 1st tx ), stool softeners (worked better for me, laxative was too strong)and this time I will have vicadin for the bad lower back pain I experienced 1st tx.  I also drank a lot of fluids days before and the week of tx. Hair started to fall out day 12 and came out in clumps on day 14.  Good luck ladies.
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 10:35AM - edited Feb 20, 2008 10:36AM by 40somethingMom The Neulasta shot is to keep your WBC count up, every onc has their own protocal, there are other forms of drugs that do the same thing.  Neulasta is expensive, but my insurance will cover, it is a one time shot.  Some of the other drugs are several shots.  Talk to your onc I'm sure she has a plan for you. Good luck You will be a FABULOUS FEB FIGHTER!
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2008 11:33AM 40somethingMom wrote: OK Aurora I had to put my wig picture in---talk about big forehead!  Good for you working out. You and your husband look very happy!  I'm down and out today, fatigue, whole body aches, is it the Neulasta from two days ago or the taxotere/cytoxan???????  I can live with this but 2nd tx is so different than 1st! I know I will start to feel better soon, the drugs are doing their job fighting the cancer!  I'm going to make my 11yr old daughter's birthday cake.  That's what keeps it real!  Donna glad to hear you are having a good day
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 04:02PM - edited Feb 27, 2008 04:03PM by 40somethingMom Well, I have to share on this thread my wonderful evening, I had a great afternoon Tuesday feeling soooo much better as it was day 8 after tx2 and se are subsiding! Only have heavy chest and sore throat today day 9!! to continue with my great evening---  Decided to meet some girls up at Ruby Tuesday's wore my wig for the occasion (I actually like wearing wraps a lot too, like some have mentioned sometimes you don't feel like hiding what you're going through) anyway, some gentleman comes over to our table and says to me, "just wanted to say, I noticed you when you came in and you are beautiful"  ha ha ha--- I looked at my friends and said you all set that up---they swore they did not and they all seemed surprised by the event, anyhow the gentleman (I think he was an angel to make my day) said "oh I'm sorry I see you have a ring on" --oh did it make my night, and I do give my wig makers credit, better than my own hair!! Nolana- good for you- good day as well!! Laurel- coffee?? I drink it have not heard not to?  don't know why I am drinking it--it tastes horrible, I keep saying here is my chance to cut down on coffee--- old habits die hard... Oh my tumor in the pelvis they say is quite common in women over 40, usually not so big, and boy am I glad to know why I have had all those symptoms in the last few years that go along with the darn thing... anyhow if chemo does not shrink it, onc says the tamoxifin will Great Day to everyone! Good luck to those starting!!!!Sunny here in Michigan again but cold!!
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2008 04:03PM 40somethingMom wrote: As good as my wig looks it is also very itchy, I actually like wearing the scarves more. I am 43, I taught school before we took a relocation for my husband's job to Lake St. Saint Louis, loved it there for 4 years, but have moved back to MI since. I currently stay home with my 2 children 11 & 8 girl/boy. I  recently decided I might go back to work part time teaching , but then decided insted to take this full time job as a cancer patient that pays nothing ha ha

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2008 10:02PM 40somethingMom wrote: Started 1/29/08 CT day1 treatment: Hyper from steroids, IV fluids combined with benadryl put me to sleep during treatment. day2  hyper from steroids, felt well got out shopping, hit a brick wall at 8pm and chills went to bed with cold sweats/ took more benadryl day3 slept in-(thank goodness mom got kids off to school) fatigue, took neulasta shot, upset  tummy but overall just fatigue-did light housework-eating fine not too hungry, drinking a lot of fluids Wonder what's to come--I'm waiting for expander until after chemotherapy, I though that might cause more discomfort during treatment?
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2008 10:17PM - edited Feb 19, 2008 11:39PM by 40somethingMom I had tx #2 today of TC.  My sister and sis-in-law came with me.  I HAD A VERY WARM AND FUZZY NURSE THIS TIME-YEAH I loved her accent.  We watched "why i wore lipstick to my mastectomy"  GREAT MOVIE ! true story originally on lifetime ch. I ordered it on ebay.  My Great nurse even let us use their tv/dvd player since my sister's laptop was not working.  How nice is that!! I made scones and everyone in the chemo room seemed to like them.  My nurse said "Excellent choice for an English woman" She even told us we could have lunch delivered to my chair for the movie (which we did) total time today was 6 hours, TC with Aloxi and Benedryl IV--pre meds emend, steroids,stool softeners, ativan(for all that anxiety) & tons of H2O Slept for a couple hours when I got home.  My lower back is throbbing tonight, but overall I feel pretty good.  I am anxious if I will experience accumulative reaction, time will tell.  Neulasta shot tomorrow--- last time I had a lot of bone pain and severe lower back pain days 5-7---this time I have the vicadin ready to go fingers crossed. Hair was shaved last week after all the loss, very itchy.  I enjoy the bandanna look the best so far.  My fav is the one from my breast cancer walk FordCares a few years ago.  Today my hubby brought home 6 new colors of bandannas from our favorite outdoor store.  I asked my 8yr old son if I drew an arrow on my forehead would I look like Avatar (cartoon character/nicktoons) he laughed and said yes. check out my new avatar(pic) no pun intended
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 10:43AM - edited Feb 20, 2008 10:52AM by 40somethingMom --delivery from tlcdirect.org was 2-3 weeks--- long time to wait in the whole treatment timing.  I loved all the items I received from that site (except the prosthesis which nothing seems to match my other breast!)  anyway the hats and halo wig I love--prices good-- you have to pay through the nose for fast delivery. Neulasta is not covered by all insurances very expensive , I hear that is why some take the 7 neupogen shots.  H2O- I feel is very important even for port or no port, I think it helps flush your system better especially when we are taking so many pre meds not to mention the chemo again  oh YEAH  AURORA-  Love seeing your the face that matches the spirit, you are beautiful GOOD LUCK TO ALL STARTING
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2008 03:57PM - edited Feb 26, 2008 03:58PM by 40somethingMom Bridget, I still remember the relief of having the tubes out!  don't be scared we are all venting, be glad this will help your future, I think most of us would agree the SE are nothing compared to the thought of this cancer returning!  Mom2daughters- unbelievable about that onco score!!  My friend is hoping for a low score to forgo chemo(i pray for her it is), mine was 25 so i was confident to do chemo.  My opinion is if your % is higher to get  leukemia from chemo it's definitely not worth doing. Good luck on TC my first tx was just fine. 2nd was rough but I was told again today by nurses I need to make sure I do the full steroid dose for tx#3 and hopefully I will not have the trouble I have encountered.  anyone from Florida, I'm sorry to hear about the situation there!
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 10:53PM 40somethingMom wrote: nolana-I had the headaches real bad 2nd tx as well, especially when my hair fell out--leg, knee, lower back, bone pains with each treatment--I'm sure neulasta shot  (vicadin has helped with all of that 2nd tx for me)--- for the record I also have had a few mouth sores, not complaining that is very minor to me, sore thoat both tx's I'll complain about that --ok done complaining
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2008 04:24PM - edited Feb 29, 2008 04:27PM by 40somethingMom Well I have to jump in and say 100% good day finally!!!!!!!!!!!And I still love my wig when I want to wear it!!!!!!!! -since I'm feeling so good we are off for hotel overnight weekend for my daughters Junior Olympic swim meet. -I picked up tree tea oil, anacin, clairitin all today for round 3 but I have the next week of heaven to enjoy(I hope) kim/aurora/nolana I hope your se are minimal   Kim/let us know about that PET- I took my CD home and my kids loved looking at it, I was amazed how my body looked and how the whole thing was so interactive on my pc --I could look through to all my organs such technology!! Reading the report is even more interesting ( one part said--there is a .5 mm nodule in the lung--can not rule out metastasis)Yikes--  not to worry my onc says that is sooo small and not in a common place for metastasis, we will watch and recheck after chemo-- and chemo would address it if it was anything.... so don't get too worried I'm trying to say those scans are very hyper sensitive and my onc says it shows everything and sometimes worries people too much about nothing grannie, krista, laura,bridgit everyone--the best
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2008 11:15AM - edited Mar 4, 2008 11:21AM by 40somethingMom Nolana-like twink said I think nails happen toward end, mine are still good-well I never have good nails so that doe not bother me although the hurt thing she mentioned does not sound good...i picked up the tree tea oil others mention, but the smell is awful so much i will not use it -bioteen wash i use & still have had these weird bumps appear 3 times after tx 2 they were sore but not like an open canker sore & then went away in a few days weird--but all of chemo has been weird wetcoast yes I have stubble appearing on my head again on this week off---can't stand it so I shave smooth, legs are still smooth, huh,  no chin hairs yeah, I I usually suffer from that in excess daily crhis- so sorry to hear you're repeating, I pray your mastectomy goes well Donna, Rachel, Aurora, Bridget---All Feb Fighters God Bless!!!!!!! oh JCS13 how are you doing? -Patricia
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2008 02:26PM 40somethingMom wrote: Artsee- I do not know which contest Aurrora was talking about, but at my chemo yesterday I picked up the CURE magizine vol.6 no.6 2007 winter www.curetoday.com and they had an artical "Healing Through Art"-survivors get creative.  I believe this is not what she was talking about but, boy did I enjoy the art.  Most looked like photo art, I really connected with the girl on the tennis court sprawled out all over the balls and there was a fantastic one of a woman looking into broken fragments of a mirror of her mastectomy, very personal to me--just sharing Patty

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2008 10:09PM 40somethingMom wrote: Donna, thanks for the nice words, i went to my LGFB class today, it was real nice, only 3 of us there, I got a free wig! cute sassy blond bob with curls, my other wig is longer & straight, so a nice fun wig.  Getting the makeup was real nice, but I enjoyed talking with the ladies the most. --My girlfriend who was on taxol alone said she thought taxol was a piece of cake compared to her 6 rounds of AC i hope the same for you! Artsee I live in the Plymouth-Canton, Close to Ann Arbor, Go Blue! Tonight my chest is heavy and heart starting to race, I'll take that damn last nuelasta in the morning.  I hope everyone else is doing the best they can! hugs Patty

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 07:47PM 40somethingMom wrote: CONGRATULATION AURORA! I could imagine you doing your happy dance -- you are so cute I wish your positive attitude would rub off on me (I should be happy to be done??), I'm at the end of second week of my last round and feeling pretty good, the taste is horrible and my lower back is achy, nose drippy and heartburn daily.  Nothing major, it's all starting to clear, but I'm feeling depressed.  Wish I could snap out of it!  I know I'm not in true menopause, I called it chemo induced menopause. EVERYONE HAVE A GREAT WEEKEND!

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2008 08:02AM - edited Feb 17, 2008 08:03AM by 40somethingMom OK, "WHAT DOES NOT KILL US ONLY MAKES US STRONGER"   Gail  Thank you for starting this chat group-- we are all cheering you on for tx 1-----You will be a Fabulous Feb Fighter!-------Chinese Sounds good!  Someone else told me spicy food is good during treatment if your tummy can handle it it's one of the few foods you can taste Donna hang in there, I hope the headaches subside for you! I remember the Mack Truck with tx 1 it seems so long ago right now and I'm a little anxious about tx 2. Aurora-  Your spirit  permeates through my computer--thank you for the uplifting words! I'm lucky to feel great today, I will test my halo wig with bandanna out at my daughter's swim meet.
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2008 08:55AM 40somethingMom wrote: I vented on the Cytoxen&Taxotere site and could not resist another hit today---  Periods have been a problem for me,(my onc did not seem to think it was any reason to hold up tx)  had it during mastectomy surgery heavy, again during TX#1 lasted two Weeks heavy!!  They found a 7" benign tumor in my pelvis during my PET so go figure I'm a piece of work, This TX #2  I'm having constant discharge.  I hope the chemo is shrinking the tumor in pelvis ---all of this makes me think YES I'm hormonal possitive & the hormones are causing all the trouble!! Wanted to share, a good friend sent me some tiny little Sterling silver boxing gloves (charm) I put them on a chain and wear them as  my FEB FIGHTER sign. Grannie- glad to hear you are doing ok Krista- glad you made the BBgame Bridgit- my heart goes out to you, I look at my mastectomy side and it looks like a malnourished person, on the other side I wonder why I ever didn't like my beautiful small breasts before-- I can not wait to have the reconstruction make me feel whole again Everyone Prayers to you all!  oh-  Ativan has been the best help for my sleeping I'm going to lie down now, I'm so blessed to not have to run to a job, but on the otherhand sometimes wish I had the commitment of a job and distraction!

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2008 03:03PM 40somethingMom wrote: sorry to hear some bad se going on with some of you-  I picked up a heating pad the other day and it is wonderful on that lower back pain-  for some reason (who am I kidding it's the CHEMO) the last couple days I have been having the lower back pains into my hips again and here I'm 2 days away from my last tx I certainly did not have many total se free days this last tx.  I'm still holding hope that #4 is easier at least it will be the last, yeah

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2008 01:19AM - edited Apr 15, 2008 01:23AM by 40somethingMom Chris- Congratulations on your last round today, I am thinking of you and hoping SE are minimal. Sorry to hear about your insurance issues Laural- I hope you are doing well with your 1st tx of taxol-the description of your valley and cows sound lovely Pam, Donna, Di, Artsee, Aurora, Rose, BD , Nolana, Bridgit, Susan- Everyone (sorry, I know I‘m forgetting someone) ---- this site has been such a wonderful outlet for the last 4 months, I can not believe I am saying that 4months, YEP since Jan. for me, but I am an official FEB FIGHTER and proud of it!! Some of you new girls need to make a new name for yourselves gosh it's April already. I had the rollercoaster emotions in the last week, I guess post chemo blues for me, I am turning it around and feeling more normal. I guess when people keep saying --Wow you're done now!, all I keep thinking is done? all the future tests, reconstruction for me, and the tomox... But I am sooooooooooooooooo happy to be done with chemo!! And sooooooooooooo thankful for all the kind words of support from each and every one of you ladies on this thread!! And thanks to all of you witty women who have made me laugh with your chemo humor--THANK YOU AND GOD BLESS YOU ALL
